subject: Technology
title: Isaac Asimov's Three Laws of Robotics
description: A short lesson to help you apply Isaac Asimov's Three Laws of Robotics.

hook.text: A science fiction writer in the 1940s created three rules for robots. Real engineers still debate them today.

buildup.text: Isaac Asimov proposed: a robot may not harm a human, must obey orders, and must protect itself, in that priority.

discovery.text: Asimov's stories explored how these simple rules led to complex moral dilemmas for his robot characters.

twist.text: Real robots don't follow Asimov's laws. Military drones and autonomous weapons violate the first law by design.

climax.text: The laws remain the starting point for every serious discussion about AI ethics and robot safety.

punchline.text: Fiction's rules for robots are still ahead of reality's regulations.

quiz.question: What is Asimov's First Law of Robotics?
options: A robot must obey all orders
A robot may not harm a human being
A robot must protect itself at all costs
